PIONEER EXPERIENCE: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A.XVI. COLLECTING INFORMATION TO THE EFFECT OF:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experience. However, some of the questions here will help you to describe your own experiences.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1924, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family answers the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires:

Western Canadian Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Western Diet: What Did You Eat?", is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ).

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to complete:

- All questionnaires
- Pioneer health conditions
- Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
- Pioneer housing and churchwork
- Pioneer education and churchwork
- Pioneer farming experience

Presentation of Questionnaires:

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of our Provincial Archives. Please send your completed questionnaires to:

Saskatchewan Archives Board,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

[Signature]

[Handwritten note]

[Stamp]
1. Your full name ........................................... Harry W. Williams

2. Your address ............................................ #65, MacRae, Sask.

3. Date ......................................................... 10/12/52

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country) .............................................. Swamped

5. What was your father's name and occupation? ............................................................ James William Gardiner

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year) ........................................ April 1905 (permanent) 1904 I took things over

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible. .......................................................... 1904 Wheatland, Manitoba

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc.) .................................................. 20 years

9. What were your reasons for coming West? .......................................................... Ill health and bent for adventure also my brother had gone to Canada the previous year.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?) .................................................. C.P.R. literature
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

That it was too far away, and that life would be primitive.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

By myself.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

Allan Steamship Line 5'5' Scimitar from Liverpool

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement etc.).

Immigrant trains were crowded and all communication was mixed in coaches until the conductor, who did not like the smell of garlic anymore than we did, separated us from the other Europeans. Saw no Indians until we got to Brandon. Montreal seemed to be a foreign city as everyone spoke French. However, the trip was enjoyable & interesting.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

Hotel at Brandon & then Wheatlands Manor

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

West of 5th Saskatchewan River Town R.R. No.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

Scott Sack.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

As a chef, accountant & office clerk to Mr. Scott & Co. By the sweat of my brow. First winter cutting firewood logs & general chores on a farm at Pandemic Man $10 per month. In Saskatchewan, harvest locating and any job to be got such as digging wells by hand 60 feet deep.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

Not very often, usually once a month.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

[Signature] L. Randle Nov 1913

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?

[Signature]

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

My brother 1903 by the Anchor Line from Liverpool
14 days in ocean Settled at Pittsfield Man
and came to Rossmere with me 1905

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

When we left Wheatland, Man. Had very little money but lot of will power. We had purchased an old team, plough, wagon, cow, stove etc. and friends gave us something & half barrel of salted pork etc. We ordered a box car which cut into our savings pretty heavily and we could not afford to buy a railroad ticket for the extra man & boxcar so we looked very much alike, we took turns hiding under the hay, and we enjoyed the excitement and tense moment when police looked things over. It took 7 days from Brandon to Stanley, Sask.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

We traveled around quite a bit within a radius of 20 miles, on foot, by buggy, no churches in the early days.
25. When was the first car used in the community?

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?
   No car

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?
   Stanley, 80 miles by day trip

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)
   No. Delisle, Watrous & New MacRae
   First car 1917 Medaughlin Bank

29. How often did you shop in the early days?
   Once a month

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?
   1913

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.
   Clothing & Hardware were got through mail order house 1906. And I would say 50% to early days & 20% now.

   Sugar was bought by the 100 lb. bag. Tea by the Coffee so the flour too. Everything was bought in quantity. It was just too bad if you ran out of tobacco, matches, tea etc. although you could sometimes borrow from settlers 60-70 miles away.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?
   MacRae Telephone Co.

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?
   Yes
24. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

Yes, adapted to farming or the loneliness of the early days.

25. Did many people move away during the 1930's? Did many return?

Yes, quite a few, and some returned although some would have liked to return but they found it financially impossible.

26. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

Thirty years School trustee also the President Agricultural association.

27. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.).

Charter member of A.F.A. M #191 started growing fruit in 1913 and have had very satisfactory results. And still continue to take any share of top prizes at Provincial Fruit Shows, almost the time engaged in corn breeding, holder 19 feet 186th at Toronto & 121st at World's Fair show Regina.

28. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.). Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name (2) origin and meaning of the name (3) date of its adoption (4) any changes in names since the first name was given date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

MacRoss was named by an Engineer of C.N.R. Post Office, Lake Otter & School after the lake nearby.
39. Questions regarding historical source materials:
Do you have in your possession or do you know the whereabouts of diaries, old letters, old posters and programs, minute books of community organizations, old pamphlets, old photographs, written recollections and reminiscences? (Describe).

Would you or the person who owns them either
(1) be willing to lend them to the Provincial Archivist for copying? .......
(2) be willing to present them to the Archives Division of the Legislative Library, Regina, or the Archives Office at the University in Saskatoon? ......
(indicate your preference, if any) ................

40. If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, where they live and occupations.

Olga Johnston Victoria, British R.C.A., A.A.
Dorothy Ewing Edmonton
Mary & William MacKenzie
Elmo J.
5 grandchildren all under 10

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?

A more affirmative attitude to what is now a thriving community
A better organization of soils and the control of weeds
The complete mechanization of farming
Improvement in homes & home surroundings

Please give the names and addresses of other pioneers who could answer this questionnaire.

Very few of the old pioneer life
and they are getting pretty feeble

If someone else has filled in this questionnaire for you, please have this person give name and address here:
